labels.name: wontfix

issues.title: Authenticator length
issues.author: BasileiosKal
issues.body:
A Token has an authenticator of constant length (Nk). For BBS, the authenticator is a proof generated by [ProofGen](https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/draft-irtf-cfrg-bbs-signatures-03#name-proof-generation-proofgen). The proof's size depends on the number of disclosed attributes.

How can this be defined?? 
- Define Nk to be N/A in the IANA registry and the authenticator to be something like `uint8_t authenticator<0..2^32>`?? 
- Remove the authenticator and add a proof field?? 
- Define a constant number of selectively disclosable items, like `[sid, iat, nonce]`?? Or not use attributes at all??

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Where does this get defined? It's not the in the architecture draft which is the main thing I looked at when writing our text.

comments.author: BasileiosKal
comments.body: Yes sorry! I was going of the [HTTP Authentication](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-privacypass-auth-scheme-11.html#name-token-redemption) and [Issuance Protocol](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-privacypass-protocol-11.html#name-issuance-protocol-for-publi) documents (was trying out the http protocol).

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-privacypass-auth-scheme-11.html#section-2.1-5 says tokens may change the type of the message, so I think Nk being NA and changing the type is fine

issues.title: Challenge use
issues.author: BasileiosKal
issues.body:
My guess is that the Client can't just send the challenge to the Issuer?? If yes, there is nothing binding a specific challenge to the BBS signature (rn the proofs are bound to the challenge). As a result, the Origin can't "force" the Client to get a "fresh" token.

Some options that come to mind:
-  Use public metadata with a low-accuracy expiration or issuance date?? (like in PR #2).
-  Use [blind BBS signatures](https://identity.foundation/bbs-signature/draft-blind-bbs-signatures.html), where the Client "commits" to the challenge during issuance (similar to how blind RSA works).

The blind BBS signatures document is out of date rn. If it's updated, should it be used instead of the core BBS protocol??

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Yeah this is not for the usual privacypass semantics where you want a token that gets spent. I want to keep things simple for now: this is just to illustrate to the WG how BBS would fit in. If they decide it's useful with some bells and whistles we'll put them in.

issues.title: What do we need in this draft?
issues.author: wbl
issues.body:
Do we just need to define the token and issuance?

Or do we need a concrete integration on top of HTTP ala the http draft from privacy pass?

I was thinking just the first aiming to be more explanatory, but could be convinced the HTTP integration is a good idea.

comments.author: BasileiosKal
comments.body:
I think @chris-wood  or @tplooker will be more qualified to answer this.

IMHO, an HTTP integration seems the way to go. its more consistent with other PP documents describing the use of specific cryptographic schemes and it will give us something concrete to implement. 

Not feeling strongly about it though. I do also see the advantage in waiting for feedback on 01.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Ok, now that I've looked at the protocol document more closely I see what you mean: that covers issuer and client interaction, but redemption to origin is done somewhere else. Specifying that might help add some concreteness, but let's see what @tplooker and @chris-wood think

comments.author: tplooker
comments.body:
> Or do we need a concrete integration on top of HTTP ala the http draft from privacy pass?

By this do you mean how to present a proof to an origin in an HTTP message? If so if there is no agreed upon way to do this in privacy pass today I would assume we would need to?

comments.author: tplooker
comments.body:
> Do we just need to define the token and issuance?

Also r.e this do you mean defining the token abstractly or defining the actual wire format? If its the latter I think there is some overlap with [JWP](https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-jmiller-jose-json-web-proof-00.html) worth considering.

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: Would have to be wire format to match what's currently there for RSA. We could just lean on JWP if that makes sense. The point was to show people in privacy pass how this would work not necessarily getting it perfect.

issues.title: Fix token type
issues.author: tfpauly
issues.body:
The draft is claiming token type = 3, which is already allocated by the adopted rate-limited draft (which also allocates 4):
https://www.ietf.org/archive/id/draft-ietf-privacypass-rate-limit-tokens-02.html#name-iana-considerations

Please use a different value that isn't already allocated, and please add IANA Considerations to correctly describe how this would be registered!

@wbl

comments.author: wbl
comments.body: I've opened a PR, they likely need some tweaking.

pulls.title: HTTP based protocol
pulls.author: BasileiosKal
pulls.body:
First stamp in an HTTP based Issuance and redemption protocol.

Using public metadata to provide the Origin with a way to check the token's "freshness".

Not sure if this document is the correct place for this?? Would be interested in peoples thoughts regardless! It could help with some decisions later (like #1).

reviews.author: wbl
reviews.body: Let's merge this and keep working. I think we're close.

comments.body: How does this work with the rest of the document and the architecture? Seems to me if we put this in we should remove some other text for clarity that's more generic.

Thank you for the review! My intent was to have the HTTP protocol as just an instantiation of the more generic protocol (that would also be described). Rn they are not really aligned. 

Opened PR #5 to take a stamp at it. If it proves to cause more confusion I'm also fine with removing some of the more generic text.

pulls.title: Adding details to generic protocol description
pulls.author: BasileiosKal
pulls.body: Trying making the HTTP protocol and the generic protocol description compatible.

pulls.title: Update draft-ladd-privacypass-bbs.md
pulls.author: wbl
pulls.body:
* Clean up some todos
* Specify encoding into Extensions, this might need revision

reviews.author: tfpauly
reviews.body:
Thanks! Clearly some things as TODO, but that's OK. The main thing is to not stomp on type 3 =) 

There are several other places where `0x0003` is used. Can you fix all of those?

comments.body: We need to add the Issuer configuration details to remove this TODO, but I do believe it will be 32 as well.
